Russia's efforts to use the Black Lives Matter movement to stoke racial tensions, and its attempts to turn Black Lives Matter supporters against Clinton, have been criticized as among the most insidious elements of Russia's 2016 election influence campaign.

On July 27, 2016, Trump said during a campaign event, "Russia, if you're listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing," referring to emails Clinton deleted from her server because she said they were personal.

The indictment revealed several new details about the breadth of the Russian influence campaign, including alleged discussions the Russian hackers allegedly had with a U.S. congressional candidate and a friendly journalist.

The Russians also "targeted state and local offices responsible for administering the elections; and sent spearphishing emails to people involved in administering elections, with malware attached," Rosenstein said.

The implication here is that Russian operatives did what Trump asked them to do, but the indictment specifically says: "There is no allegation in this indictment that any American citizen committed a crime."

According to the indictment, that same day, Russians "attempted after hours to spearphish for the first time email accounts at a domain hosted by a third party server used by Clinton's personal office."
From one state election board, the Russians managed to steal information on 500,000 voters, Rosenstein said, although he did not identify which state.
A journalist allegedly discussed with the Russian front account, Guccifer 2.0, about when to release stolen documents related to Black Lives Matter.
"On or about August 15, 2016, the conspirators received a request for stolen documents from a candidate for U.S. Congress," the indictment said.
He stressed, however, that the indictments contained "no allegation that the conspiracy altered the vote count or changed any election result."

The reporter, who is not named in the indictment, also "offered to write an article" about the release of the stolen documents.
The allegations in Friday's indictment went well beyond merely hacking the Clinton campaign and Democratic campaign committees.
The Russians allegedly hacked America's election infrastructure, including state election boards and secretaries of state.
Despite this, Trump has made no changes to his plan to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday in Helsinki.
According to the indictment, the operatives allegedly provided stolen campaign documents to a candidate for Congress.
Trump won the 2016 election by winning three key states by slim margins that added up to around 80,000 votes.
Below are some key takeaways from the indictment, released by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.
Russian hackers targeted Clinton emails the same day Trump called for them to find "missing" emails.
"I briefed President Trump about these allegations earlier this week," Rosenstein said Friday.
The conspirators "sent the candidate stolen documents related to the candidate's opponent."
"The President is fully aware of today’s actions by the Department."
Trump knew about these indictments well before they were announced.
Trump said to a reporter, "And I will absolutely bring that up.
"I know you'll ask, 'will we be talking about meddling?'"
The candidate was not identified in the indictment.
Nor does the indictment name any Americans.
I will absolutely firmly ask the question."
